questions.question_text: A hospital wants to offer indoor directions to patient rooms utilizing its existing wireless infrastructure. The wireless network has been using location services specifications. Which two components must be installed to support this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Cisco MSE (Mobility Services Engine):

The Cisco MSE is a platform that provides advanced location-based services, including real-time location tracking and analytics. It works with the existing wireless infrastructure to enable indoor navigation and wayfinding.

The MSE collects data from wireless access points and uses it to calculate the location of devices, which is essential for providing indoor directions.

Cisco CMX Visitor Connect:

Cisco CMX Visitor Connect is a component of the Cisco Connected Mobile Experiences (CMX) solution that provides wayfinding and indoor navigation capabilities. It integrates with the MSE to offer turn-by-turn directions to specific locations, such as patient rooms.

Visitor Connect also allows for customization of the navigation experience, making it suitable for a hospital environment.

Cisco MSE (Mobile Services Engine) is required to provide accurate location information for indoor directions. It uses Wi-Fi infrastructure to track and locate devices within the hospital.

Cisco CMX AppEngage is needed to deliver personalized indoor directions to patient rooms. It enables the hospital to create and manage location-based campaigns and notifications that can be sent to patients’ mobile devices.

Together, Cisco MSE and Cisco CMX AppEngage provide the necessary components to support indoor directions using the existing wireless infrastructure.

Selected Answer: BD
Based on video shared by Zanjit500 I would agree answer is B. and D.

B & D

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQRb8vfU0qM

Selected Answer: BC
Hardware : MSE
Service : Visitor Connect

choices.D: Separate the controllers into different mobility groups per controller.
choices.C: Configure the controllers into separate RF groups from the mobility groups.
choices.B: Remove unnecessary controllers from the mobility group.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
While multicast can optimize certain message transmissions, it doesn’t directly reduce the number of mobility messages exchanged between controllers.

By removing unnecessary controllers, you reduce the load on each controller while maintaining the same number of mobility messages between the required controllers.

comments.content: We recommend multicast messaging for large mobility groups.

discussion.content:
provided answer is correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-5/config-guide/b_cg85/mobility_groups.html

questions.question_text: When configuring a large, high-availability wireless network, which change to a mobility group creates less load on the controllers and maintains the same mobility messages?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
D. Allow UDP ports 5246 and UDP port 5247 on the firewall.
These ports are used for communication between the OEAP and the WLC (Wireless LAN Controller). Allowing them ensures the OEAP can establish a connection to the controller.
E. Allow UDP ports 12222 and 12223 on the firewall.
These ports are also used for CAPWAP (Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) communication between the OEAP and the WLC, enabling the AP to join the controller.

Selected Answer: BD
Going with B. and D. on this one but I agree with anagy11 comment that the wording "on the firewall" is confusing. D. and E. would be the only 2 answers that you make sense from that perspective but OEAP does not require ports 12222 and 12223 so E. makes no sense in that regard. Terrible question wording.

 Corporate Firewall

The Wireless LAN Controller should be placed in DMZ and the corporate Firewall must allow CAPWAP Control and CAPWAP Data traffic through the Firewall to the Wireless LAN Controller.The general configuration on the firewall is to allow CAPWAP control and CAPWAP management port numbers through the firewall.
Note 

The UDP 5246 and 5247 ports need to be opened on the firewall for communication between the Wireless LAN controller and the Cisco OfficeExtend Access Point 1810.

Selected Answer: BD
Strange question wording...
"Which two configurations must be performed on the firewall to allow the AP to join the controller?"
on the firewall...

B. Enable NAT Address on the 5520 with an Internet-routable IP address.
&
D. Allow UDP ports 5246 and UDP port 5247 on the firewall.
is correct https://mrncciew.com/2013/03/12/how-does-oeap-work/
should be DE?

comments.content:
Agree, it is D and E.D.
Allow UDP ports 5246 and UDP port 5247 on the firewall: These are the default ports used by lightweight APs to communicate with the WLC for control and data traffic.

E. Allow UDP ports 12222 and 12223 on the firewall: These are the default ports used by CAPWAP for APs to communicate with the WLC.

questions.question_text: A corporation has employees working from their homes. A wireless engineer must connect 1810 OEAP at remote teleworker locations. All configuration has been completed on the controller side, but the network readiness is pending. Which two configurations must be performed on the firewall to allow the AP to join the controller? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Allow UDP ports 12222 and 12223 on the firewall.
choices.B: Enable NAT Address on the 5520 with an Internet-routable IP address.
choices.A: Block UDP ports 1812 and 1813 on the firewall.
choices.C: Configure a static IP on the OEAP 1810.
choices.D: Allow UDP ports 5246 and UDP port 5247 on the firewall.
Set the auto containment level to 4 and select the Using Our SSID containment option.
choices.C: Set the auto containment level to 0 and select the Ad Hoc Rogue AP containment option.
choices.B: Set the manual containment level to 4 and select the Ad Hoc Rogue AP containment option.
choices.A: Set the auto containment level to 0 and select the Using Our SSID containment option.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer is D.
Honeypot attacks: A honeypot AP spoofs the SSID (and eventually MAC) of a real AP.
Level 0 containment does not exist.
Using our SSID option ensures that any rogue AP with the same SSID as "My Network" is contained.

comments.content: At the first I agreed with you,bBut the questions stand for Cisco Prime Infrastructure. Using our SSID option is for WLC. So, I think i will stay for B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the most logical answer here.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/mse/3350/7-3/wIPS_Configuration_guide/Guide/wIPS/msecg_appB_wIPS.html

The two answers with 0 containment aren't even valid options as the level is 1-4. Containing your own SSID makes no sense, so B is the only option left.

Selected Answer: D
Auto Containment Level to 4:

Setting the auto containment level to 4 ensures that rogue APs are automatically contained as soon as they are detected. This level provides the most aggressive containment, which is necessary to prevent honeypot attacks and protect the network from unauthorized access points.

Using Our SSID Containment Option:

The Using Our SSID containment option ensures that rogue APs broadcasting the organization's SSID are contained. This is critical for preventing honeypot attacks, where attackers mimic the organization's SSID to lure clients into connecting to a malicious AP.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/4400-series-wireless-lan-controllers/112045-handling-rogue-cuwn-00.html#toc-hId-715491869:~:text=Use%20of%20our%20SSID%20%2D%20If%20a%20rogue%20device%20uses%20an%20SSID%20which%20is%20the%20same%20as%20that%20configured%20on%20the%20controller%2C%20it%20is%20automatically%20contained.%20This%20feature%20aims%20to%20address%20a%20honey%2Dpot%20attack%20before%20it%20causes%20damage.

Use of our SSID - If a rogue device uses an SSID which is the same as that configured on the controller, it is automatically contained. This feature aims to address a honey-pot attack before it causes damage.

Selected Answer: D
Use of our SSID - If a rogue device uses an SSID which is the same as that configured on the controller, it is automatically contained. This feature aims to address a honey-pot attack before it causes damage.


https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/4400-series-wireless-lan-controllers/112045-handling-rogue-cuwn-00.html#toc-hId-715491869
Who can share the menue path to implement solution D on Prime 3.10? Unable to find it.

Selected Answer: D
D. Agree with Mimimimimi, level 0 is not an option. Using own SSID is correct. The legit corp access points will send de-authentication messages to any client connected to the rouge AP on the corp SSID. It will not effect users connected to legit access points.

Selected Answer: B
I did it on a testsystem:
Dashboard > Incidents > Rogue Alarms > Open a destinctive Alarm > "AP containment" option > select "4 AP containment"

The wording of "B" is really bad, but at least, I was able to use "B" as hint and to find the menue items in Prime 3.10 to complete this task.
My prime is running in KVM and RHEL8 using the 12Gig RAM installation option. Disk is SAMSUNG SSD with 1000 MByte/s peak throughput

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D
Use of our SSID - If a rogue device uses an SSID which is the same as that configured on the controller, it is automatically contained. This feature aims to address a honey-pot attack before it causes damage.

questions.question_text:
A healthcare organization notices many rogue APs and is concerned about a honeypot attack. Which configuration must a wireless network engineer perform in
Cisco Prime Infrastructure to prevent these attacks most efficiently upon detection?

discussion.content:

comments.content: This is for CMX Visitor Connect which uses a guest captive portal that allows easy onboarding of the guests. It's different from CMX Facebook Wi-Fi. The workflows are very similar, but they are different in that with Facebook Wifi the guest will land on the venue owner's Facebook page
